events.target_title: [Feature Request] Slideshow

note.body:
Script if anyone comes across this.

```
#!/bin/bash
directory="/home/justin/Wallpapers/"
# Interval in minutes
interval="15"

# Get list of wallpapers into file
ls -b ${directory} > /tmp/wallpaper-list

while :
  do
    wp1=$(shuf -n 1 /tmp/wallpaper-list)
    wp2=$(shuf -n 1 /tmp/wallpaper-list)
    hydrapaper -c ${directory}${wp1} ${directory}${wp2}
    sleep $((${interval}*60))
done
```

events.target_title: Nautilus does not enable to connect to an NFS share

note.body:
I'm a redhat 7 user and I was trying to mount an NFS export through Nautilus, and I was confused as to why it wouldn't accept the address despite the help message saying NFS was a supported protocol.

It turns out RedHat has the `gvfs-smb` package, but not the `gvfs-nfs` package.
So any RedHat users who want to mount an NFS export will run into this issue.

GNOME To Do doesn't parse updates from Nextcloud unless you log off/log in

note.body:
It does not have to be an "anti-pattern" to an already existing automatic update. It is an addition. So a user can seamlessly work on tasks and they get automatically updated, *and*, they have the option to pull changes whenever they need with a simple button click, as opposed to some hidden mechanism that cannot be triggered when necessary.

To give you an example, I may work at my phone and update my Google tasks in the morning, then work at my desktop and praying that when I open the app, it will pull new data I just added, step away for lunch and add new data using the phone, and come back half an hour later to realize nothing is synced and one doesn't have a 'refresh' button to trigger a sync. This is very annoying.

events.target_title: Tutorial generates error in `class HelloGNOME`
Define nightlight sunset/sunrise as mid point of the transition rather than end

note.body: For my own app sunrise is the start of transition which lasts for 90 minutes. Then 90 minutes before sunset transition starts and sunset is the end of transition. User can set period from 60 to 120 minutes (or anything) though. Brightness and gamma changes occur every 70 seconds because point jumps < 21 don't work on intel hd 530 hardware (intel_backlight) laptop display. Point jumps of 1 do work on intel hd 3000 so 15 seconds was the interval for changing brightness & gamma on that platform. For external monitors xrandr must be used for --brightness changes which work in .01 increments. HTH.

Re: the squarespace event, it does not appear in the log, except in response to the REPORT.  The log _does_ contain data for another event that appears after the squarespace event, so perhaps my theory is incorrect.

But there does seem to be something to the @ vs %40 with this particular server, which could very well be out of spec, but is handled by other clients.

Re: the patch, I can give compiling evolution-data-server a try, but it might take me a while!

events.target_title: CalDAV: Unescape URI path parts during refresh in iCloud

note.body:
I've confirmed that the calendars with these "@" events load successfully in Thunderbird and macOS Calendar.  They do not load correctly in Windows 10's calendar or Evolution.

I have reported the issue to Apple using their feedback assistant.  It remains to be seen if they have any interest in making their CalDAV server work with clients on other platforms.  I'm not expecting much, but hopefully they will do the right thing.

While I respect and understand your position that the Gnome client is following the spec and the server is not, I would encourage you to consider a "quirks mode" or server-specific preference that could possibly be applied to the icloud.com CalDAV server.  I know that feels like adding cruft to support something that isn't your fault, but a lot of times what seems like "cruft" actually adds value and empowers users.  My belief is that clients of open protocols have somewhat of a responsibility to their users to be liberal in what they accept from servers, if the quirk can reasonably be corrected automatically or the user manually requests that behavior.  Obviously servers have a responsibility to follow protocol too -- but often the user is left powerless when they are not also the administrator of the server.

(For example, my company works on an (S)FTP client and there are _so many_ server quirks that, if we didn't accommodate them, would render our client useless for a many, many people, because the servers will simply never be fixed.  We feel a duty to our users to workaround these issues on their behalf so that they have a smooth experience.)

My other workaround, of course, would be to delete the problem events.  However, it's a short-term solution, as I will likely receive other such events in the future.

I'll leave it up to you how to proceed!  You may close this issue if you do not feel any changes should be made to Evolution.  Thank you very much for your help investigating this.  I learned a lot!

note.body:
#16 would have me think that arbitrary options are not, and probably never will be, supported.

Until then, I have diverted the openvpn binary
```
dpkg-divert --divert /usr/sbin/openvpn.real --rename /usr/sbin/openvpn
```

to the following wrapper script (`/usr/sbin/openvpn`):
```
#!/bin/sh
EXTRA=""

if echo "$@" | grep -q "remote IP.ADDR.OF.GATEWAY" ; then
	EXTRA="--tls-version-min 1.0"
fi

exec /usr/sbin/openvpn.real $EXTRA "$@"
```

Kludgy, but it works for me until the NM plugin officially supports that option ;)

note.body: Not exactly.  ('why?' is a hard question to answer.)  However, Darwin uses g_osx_app_info_*() instead of g_desktop_app_info_*().  lib/libgio-* defines symbols for the former and include/glib-2.0/gio/gosxappinfo.h declares them.  g_desktop_app_info_*() functions are declared in the installed file include/gio-unix-2.0/gio/gdesktopappinfo.h but symbols are not defined in any library.

Show battery level next to bluetooth devices that support it

note.body:
So you say, but as a Fedora 30 Workstation user that has been trying to find the supposed Bluetooth battery level...

You say this is on the "Power panel". Well, what if we're on a desktop and that panel isn't a thing? Why can't there be a spot in settings to see battery levels?

![Screenshot_from_2019-07-27_11-57-51](/uploads/147800b4f033702d4e2658133c84a955/Screenshot_from_2019-07-27_11-57-51.png)
![Screenshot_from_2019-07-27_11-57-32](/uploads/0bbd6c672e80102318acbcd318f016df/Screenshot_from_2019-07-27_11-57-32.png)

I **cannot add or modify panels on the taskbar**, so I cannot access this "power panel" you speak of. Giving me zero way to access the battery levels of Bluetooth devices.

And, even if I could enable the power panel, what would it do when I have 3+ Bluetooth devices connected? Would each get its own battery indicator?

![Screenshot_from_2019-07-27_12-00-21](/uploads/822c225e10ca0d396aa848898d42e43d/Screenshot_from_2019-07-27_12-00-21.png)

---

Disclaimer: While I may be a Linux power user, I am also 90% blind, so while you may be able to "write your own application to query Bluez over DBus to view the battery level of your Bluetooth devices" -- this is hardly an "acceptable solution". I may as well not even be using a DE if that were the only option. ("write it yourself.")

---

After some research, "Gnome Panels" don't even come on Fedora 30 Workstation, we have "Dash to Panel" installed by default, which replaces the "Flashback Panels" with a single (Windows-like) taskbar at the bottom of the screen, which does not accept applets.

EXTENSIONS work just fine, as can be seen on my screenshot (caffiene, accessibility menu, onesystembutton, etc.) but NOT PANELS. This has left me at a stalemate as per "adding the power panel".

---

P.P.P.S: This message is so long because I am sick and tired of Googling "Gnome Bluetooth Battery" just to come back to this page alone, where the only answer is "lol, nah, we already have this feature." Then, trying to reproduce the "existing feature" simply gave me nothing. I did this search three months ago when I installed Fedora 30, then again every week later... eventually got fed up and here we are.

events.target_title: pango-font.h has wrong include file

note.body:
Hello,

@khaledh, exactly. On Archlinux the `harfbuzz` header files are installed under `/usr/include/harfbuzz` and seems that is default path for upstream. So I'm a bit confused, do you say that harfbuzz files have to be installed under `/usr/include` and **NOT** into `/usr/include/harfbuzz`? What about `pango-coverage.h`? It uses `#include <harfbuzz/hb.h>`.

I checked that both Ubuntu/Debian and Fedora install `.h` files under `/usr/include/harfbuzz`. Did I missed something? Could it be a problem with `pkgconfig`? Or with CMake?

As I mentioned above I faced with the problem when compile Remmina that uses CMake. I don't know how CMake process `.pc` file, may be it didn't process `Requires.private` correctly.

---
WBR, Vladimir Lomov

events.target_title: pango-font.h has wrong include file

note.body: @david-geiger, it's a problem of Remmina (they use "home-grown" `FindGTK3.cmake` and it should be updated, I already [reported](https://gitlab.com/Remmina/Remmina/issues/1941) that but they will update the file only after release), I think after moving 'harfbuzz' dependency from `Requires.private` to `Requires` in `.pc` all would be fine (when `FindGTK3.cmake` will be updated).

events.target_title: Incremental backups of changed vdi files
Incremental backups of changed vdi files

note.body:
Thanks for you feedback. I do acknowledge that incremental backups are supported, but when processing a .vdi file "VirtualBox Virtual Disk Image" in my case used in virtual box, the program goes into a never ending process. Tried it for more than 12 hours and couldn't go past the 1rst .vdi file.
When I point them out as ignore .vdi files, the incremental backup process ok. So I was wondering if they were supported.

The version I'm using is through ubuntu default package manager.

events.target_title: Incremental backups of changed vdi files

note.body: For anybody else that is going through my same hurdle, i figured out that only for incremental backups is where .vdi files goes into never ending loop. A full backup will work. Actually I tested it by accident and help me recover all the data from the full first backup and the last incremental done ignoring the .vdi's. For now I will consider this case close due to I found a workaround that fulfill my needs. This tool is great and I will continue using it from now on.

note.body: It seems that `gf_output_get_assigned_crtc` is returning a `NULL` `GfCrtc` pointer, via a call to `gf_output_get_instance_private`, which I cannot find a reference to here.

Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
Alas, while it is possible to convert bitmap PCF fonts into bitmap-only OTB fonts using fontforge, the result is very far from even remotely satisfactory once the converted fonts are rendered with the new Pango v1.44.1 via HarfBuzz.

Here are examples, with Adobe Helvetica:

Pretty and readable: [Pango-1.43.0-Freetype-PCF-Helvetica.png](https://reho.st/self/ccb8dff3caabcfc9c8b2116cedaeea45d445c714.png)

Ugly and badly spaced: [Pango-1.44.1-HarfBuzz-OTB-Helvetica.png](https://reho.st/self/4a07aa318232e8d70248e45fa5233966248e0d25.png)

I for one will stick with Pango v1.43... :-(

PS: you will note in the screen shots that the window title is properly drawn in both cases, but that's just because the window manager in use (Sawfish) is not using Pango to render it.

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
Why not, instead, allowing to use *both* or *either* of Freetype and HarfBuzz in Pango, be it at runtime (e.g. with an exported environment variable) or at compile time (it would then let every distro the freedom to compile with Freetype or HarfBuzz support) ?

Also, I find it extremely disturbing that such a HUGE breakage in functionality takes place with just a minor version bump... It would deserve a v2 numbering, at the very least.

Nowadays, many people tend to mistake "innovation" for "progress", but I'm sorry to say that the Harfbuzz innovation in Pango is a regression. :-(

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
And what about resolving this issue with Freetype developers ?... I mean, if it is really broken, it's a bug that should be fixed in Freetype.
That, or get Harfbuzz developers to implement proper bitmap fonts support.

In any case, I'm not going to keep updating Pango if it means being unable to use bitmap fonts on my systems. If you guys don't find a way to resolve properly this unacceptable breakage, I guess I will have to create a private fork for Pango, because there is no way I'm going to use all those silly, ugly, fuzzy, sight-destroying truetype fonts on my systems. Bitmap fonts are pixel-perfect, but I guess it's considered a "progress" to use fuzzy looking fonts that kill your eyes...

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
I tried with the latest fontforge versions (20190801 and 20190413), in case the very bad results I got so far would be due to a fontforge issue, but unlike the super-old one I used before (and that allowed me to convert PCF fonts to OTB fonts), those ones refuse to convert the PCF fonts to anything, always producing an empty file and displaying an error message box like: "The font database does not contain a bitmap of size 12 and depth 0"...

So, even this option seems closed now. :-(

Help users to add a remote scanner available in the local network

note.body:
I have a multi function Brother device that can scan through network (it is not attached directly to this computer) and isn't found here.

It would actually make this application useful for me if it could. As-is I have zero use for simple-scan. So +1 for something though I would rather it be actual implementation instead of tips - jumping through hoops isn't the best way to go about things.

To add to to this, hoop jumping, looks like https://help.ubuntu.com/community/sane (rpm and deb) I assume is the way to get it working right now for Bother, HP, and Samsung scanners... I wonder if even simple scripts tied into the menu could do it in one click which would be better than nothing. (I've not tried this and at least at this time probably won't since I can just boot into Windows and scan). - Though this doesn't cover 100% of all scanners so kind of worthless in that way (the dumb backwards way of doing things).

events.target_title: Tabs and ctrl+tab shortcut
Unable to open folders in Mac Catalina: "Operation not permitted"

note.body:
I allow to add the following precisions :

Pure local files in pure local folders, i.e. /Users/myusername/myfile.xcf can be opened in Gimp.
Files and folders which are synced with iCloud and which had for example been in /Users/myusername/Documents in previous macOS versions but have now been physically moved over to /Users/myusername/Library/CloudStorage/iCloud Drive/Documents in Catalina throw the error described above when trying to access via the File Open / Save as / Export as menu.

Al least for opening existing files, there is a workaround:
Open a Finder window, navigate to the (iCloud) folder containing the desired xcf file, right click and select Open with Gimp 2.10. Files opened this way can also be modified and saved afterwards without problems.

Conclusion: The problem is not directly with Gimp, but "only" with its File (open/save/export) dialog which can't correctly handle the new iCloud related file paths introduced with Catalina.

The weird thing is that even going through System settings -> Security and Confidentiality -> Full Disk access and adding Gimp there won't solve the problem which means that there is obviously a substantial problem with Gimp's File/Directory dialog.

Lollypop crashes on boot 100% - int() argument must be a string, a bytes-like object or a number, not 'slice'

note.body:
Really sorry to be the bearer of bad news, but this has not fixed the 18.04 issue. I'm getting pretty much an identical crash, but this time in view_album.

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/lollypop/view_album.py", line 124, in _on_map
    GLib.Variant("ai", self.__genre_ids))
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/gi/overrides/GLib.py", line 242, in __new__
    (v, rest_format, _) = creator._create(format_string, [value])
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/gi/overrides/GLib.py", line 137, in _create
    return self._create_array(format, args)
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/gi/overrides/GLib.py", line 221, in _create_array
    (v, rest_format, _) = self._create(format[1:], args[0][i:])
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/gi/overrides/GLib.py", line 428, in __getitem__
    key = int(key)
TypeError: int() argument must be a string, a bytes-like object or a number, not 'slice'
```

I would humbly suggest the same fix (https://gitlab.gnome.org/World/lollypop/commit/77cf4bf452f7a0e257f0b67a828a1315944555ba) may need to be applied in a number of places :

```
view_album.py
124:                                 GLib.Variant("ai", self.__genre_ids))
126:                                 GLib.Variant("ai", self.__artist_ids))
128:                                 GLib.Variant("ai", [self._album.id]))

view_albums_box.py
146:                                         GLib.Variant("ai", self.__genre_ids))
148:                                         GLib.Variant("ai", self.__artist_ids))
151:                                         GLib.Variant("ai", self.__artist_ids))

view_albums_list.py
710:                                     GLib.Variant("ai", self.__genre_ids))
712:                                     GLib.Variant("ai", self.__artist_ids))
715:                                     GLib.Variant("ai", self.__artist_ids))

view_artist_small.py
67:                                     GLib.Variant("ai", self._genre_ids))
69:                                     GLib.Variant("ai", self._artist_ids))
```

Thanks for replying so quickly, sorry to be a pain ;)

Paul.

note.body:
This probably doesn't help your diagnosis but I ran my application overnight and in the morning Metacity was using 5.1GB. When I switched from Metacity to Compiz and then straight back to Metacity it was then using only 39.5MB. My application continues to run and the system is responsive but it will eventually run out of memory...

My application issues large numbers of OpenGL renderings but that isn't at all odd. It periodically does a glFinish() to keep the GPU pipeline clear. The only "peculiarity" about my hardware is that I have two 4K screens.

events.target_title: Metacity memory leak

note.body: It is a large program of my own. It uses OpenGL and GLSL and it isn't very practical to send you it. I could package up a version but you'd have to trust that it isn't malware. note.body:

Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
For others affected that are having trouble figuring out how to use your bitmap fonts with the new pango version from the comments above, here's a guide:

##### 1. Identify your font file

In a terminal, run `strace -fe trace=file gtk2fontsel`. You'll have the terminal window and a font-selection window:

![pango-bitmap-conversion-guide](/uploads/6e24d09898370b66420faa778b7084bb/pango-bitmap-conversion-guide.png)

In the terminal window, hit Enter a bunch of times to create spacing with the text that's already there. Then, in the font-selection window, find and select the font you want, *in the style and size you want* (since different styles and sizes may correspond with different files):

![pango-bitmap-conversion-guide-2](/uploads/c5d3eb47a15e1435f4a678d252a51a8a/pango-bitmap-conversion-guide-2.png)

The last font file that appears opened in the terminal window is what you want. It's what I highlighted in the picture above. Copy that path.

##### 2. Convert your font file

Open up `fontforge` and paste the path of the font file in the file dialog it gives you:

![pango-bitmap-conversion-guide-3](/uploads/b642baa72af544825df0f25b780e7dbb/pango-bitmap-conversion-guide-3.png)

Once you've opened up the file, open up the "File" menu, and click on "Generate Fonts...":

![pango-bitmap-conversion-guide-4](/uploads/52ca59fba904fabfbce006a49c03493f/pango-bitmap-conversion-guide-4.png)

Then in the dialog it opens, in the left select box where it probably says "No Outline Font", select "OpenType (CFF)". In the select box to the right of that, where it might say "No Bitmap Fonts", select "In TTF/OTF":

![pango-bitmap-conversion-guide-5](/uploads/73096609ad1253270bb85ad5002b503b/pango-bitmap-conversion-guide-5.png)

You can save it in `~/.local/share/fonts/`, so apps can see it.

##### 3. Find the new font name to reconfigure your apps

The name of the font might have changed. In my case, it changed from "Misc Fixed" to simply "Fixed". I don't know what determines these things. Anyway, in that case you'll have to somehow figure out what the resulting name is and change whatever you have configured to use that font to use the new name.

You can use the same trick as the first step, using `strace -fe trace=file gtk2fontsel`. Just select fonts that might be it, and see when your file appears opened up in the terminal.

You can also use `inotifywait -m ~/.local/share/fonts/$your_font_file`. That command will tell you when your file has been opened.

![pango-bitmap-conversion-guide-6](/uploads/ae648f76702131d746459774a4ce3c6d/pango-bitmap-conversion-guide-6.png)

In the font-selection window, using the arrow key, quickly pass through all fonts until output appears from inotifywait.

![pango-bitmap-conversion-guide-7](/uploads/70f3201fee8d8527699a084a19965983/pango-bitmap-conversion-guide-7.png)

All that's left is to reconfigure your programs to use the new font name.

events.target_title: Nearest color selection (from color reduction) is fatal

note.body:
GIMP's nearest color selection is neither standard nor perceptual, which is the worst of both worlds.

![image](/uploads/08aed46e14a2d1f48fee80888b9d0a58/image.png)
![image](/uploads/d556f07b56be08787747bcdbe03dda8f/image.png)

GIMP's nearest color selection is **nowhere near the standard method** (sum the differences between channels, weighted by 0.299 for Red, 0.587 for Green and 0.114 for Blue) and **nowhere near a perceptual method** (calculate the weighted Euclidean distance between Linear channels then adjust the difference value to sRGB) that I implemented myself.

events.target_title: Nearest color selection (from color reduction) is fatal

note.body:

![image](/uploads/476310394e6af4d348b2708832089a91/image.png)
![image](/uploads/e6978c24114dd258f605e517d8110d91/image.png)

Once again, GIMP's algorithm is nowhere near standard, nowhere near perceptual. Why would I want to use the GIMP's algorithm that's more irregular and less accurate than both standard and perceptual?

events.target_title: Tracking: Transparent encryption and signing with GPG

note.body:
Hi,

pEp is neither PGP nor is it still using GnuPG – we are complete switching to https://sequoia-pgp.org/ with the coming versions.

pEp is a concept how to make encryption transparent to the user up to the point where there is no UI any more. It's also a concept what and how to communicate to the user by default (by using traffic light colors for “can I trust the privacy protection of this message”).

pEp is compatible to PGP. The next version of pEp will be compatible to S/MIME, too. This means, pEp is sending pEp format to pEp commincation partners, while it's sending PGP format to PGP communication partners (and it will send S/MIME next version to S/MIME comm partners).

The pEp format is downwards compatible with PGP/MIME. This means, if you don't have pEp but you've access to a pEp message and some PGP implementation you can decrypt and read – while this may not be perfect user experience it guarantees readability of all data.

pEp is valuing all attacks on communication high, which can be used for privacy breaches. Therefore, pEp has a three step rating concept (communication type, rating, color/symbol) and a two step trust implementation against Man-in-the-middle-attacks (TOFU, Trustwords instead of comparing fingerprints).

Technically, pEp engine is a library. This library is not meant to be used directly but by having a pEp adapter for application development. pEp adapters are available for different programming environments and languages. Additionally, there's a standard interface defined in JSON, which can be used through a socket, and which is always available on all Desktop implementations.

For GNOME pEp foundation is searching for a developer for pEp GNOME adapter supporting GLib directly. We've budget and want to finance this. This can be helpful for all GNOME applications.

pEp can be applied on E-Mail. We've got an implementation for IBM MQ, too, so we've got the PoC that pEp can be applied to very different messaging systems without modification.

If you have questions I'm happy to help. If you're searching for a cool project let's talk about implementing pEp GNOME adapter ;-) If you're interested in implementing pEp in your MUA, messenger or messaging system, please tell me how I can support you!

Yours,
VB.

events.target_title: Tracking: Transparent encryption and signing with GPG

note.body:
Actually, we still support GnuPG, because Enigmail is using it. It's a build option. But because Sequoia PGP is not only easier to use but also incredibly faster we're switching with all of our own plugins and applications (Enigmail is from Enigmail project, it's not from us).

CryptoContext is looking like an interface, which can be implemented for Sequoia. pEp is one level higher: we're automating key management, identity management and trust management.

Adding pEp to an MUA does not require to know about algorithms, digests, etc. It does not require to know about keys. The basic idea is a loop-through interface: you throw every incoming message (including unencrypted messages) through decrypt_message() and every outgoing through encrypt_message(), and pEp decides if encryption can be switched on or decryption is needed and does the job whenever needed.

Then pEp is about user interface: instead of manually managing keys and showing encryption and signature status pEp is about showing privacy status only: can the user rely on that his privacy was/will being kept or not? The rating results are coming with the according API calls. Also Trustwords checking is in the API. 

Then pEp is sporting pEp sync (yes, the actual version has it now): synchronization of keys (implemented), trust, contacts, calendar, etc. (future versions). That means, if pEp autodetects that another device is using the same inbox (i.e. the user has a smartphone and a laptop) it offers the possibility to keep the two devices in sync.

pEp is requiring implementing search in encrypted mails. For this pEp has the concept to trust the encryption of the hard disk or flash of the local device. Then a pEp app will have a local search index for encrypted mail on untrusted servers.

BTW: Enigmail decided to do their own implementation, which is only a subset of what pEp does. If you want to get an impression, grab an actual Beta of pEp for Android. This is much more complete.

How does the financing work? Well, we could offer a bounty. We also can just offer to pay someone for doing the job based on monthly rates as a freelancer.

events.target_title: Tracking: Transparent encryption and signing with GPG

note.body: BTW: it's quite easy to implement a migration from GnuPG to Sequoia PGP. Did that for pEp for Outlook.

events.target_title: Tracking: Transparent encryption and signing with GPG

note.body:
We're already funding Sequoia PGP, an alternative to GnuPG:

https://sequoia-pgp.org/

events.target_title: Tracking: Transparent encryption and signing with GPG

note.body:
I'm sure whatever option is chosen it will be the GNOME keyring.

Sequoia PGP have the concept of having backends for Key Stores anyway.

pEp is not PGP, though. We're downwards compatible when communicating to PGP users. We will implement GMOME keyring. But pEp is only interested in real pEp applications. There is a reason why PGP applications never get traction with users since 25 years: users don't understand keys and they don't understand crypto nor the technology needed for this. And most users are even not interested. They want the machine to be secure not being responsible themselves. If you want to implement manual crypto for nerds (like it is everywhere today), I think directly implementing Sequoia PGP is the best way to do it. In our tests it's nowhere less than 20 times faster than GnuPG. And it's very easy to implement compared to GPGME. The quality is impressive. I love this software.

pEp is developing pEp for Thunderbird (unrelated to Enigmail) because of users complaining about complexity and missing features in Enigmail, which all other pEp apps have: search in encrypted mails, pEp Sync, etc. Enigmail decided to implement a broad range of technologies, which is a good thing for a competent group of users. But it's not good to make it product for the masses. Also the GnuPG dependency frequently breaks our code base, because the next update is not API compatible (we have this just now again). The decision of Enigmail to always use the newest GnuPG version before we have a chance to test it is making us headaches.

We would love to support GNOME by helping implementing pEp in MUAs if the owners of these projects want this. If the owners of these MUAs don't want it we will not again make compromizes like we did with Enigmail. We will most likely develop a real pEp implementation in Evolution and offer our cooperation there. If wanted we'll invest.

If people want to stick with PGP, well, there's always other options ;-) I'm highly recommending using Sequoia PGP then, even without pEp. But this is a decision of the MUA project owners, of course.

events.target_title: Tracking: Transparent encryption and signing with GPG

note.body: In this case I'm suggesting using Sequoia PGP. That's exactly the game this software is designed for.

events.target_title: Tracking: Transparent encryption and signing with GPG

note.body:
@anna: pEp mainly is an implementation of a UX concept. The pEp concept is including automated trust management to fight MITM attacks, key management without key servers or any central infrastructure, identity management to make peer-to-peer synchronization between user's devices possible, etc. It is providing a concept how to have search in encrypted mails. It is differentiating between trusted (own) mail servers and untrusted ones in the cloud. It has optional enterprise features to support network virus scanners, network debugging for admins in enterprises, and so forth.

pEp is not bound to email. We've implemented it for other messaging tech, too (we're doing this to encrypt transaction messages for banks). But pEp is sporting a complete feature package for email, including more secure message formats, avoiding the attack vectors i.e. EFail was based on, etc.

I think it is quite a decision for an MUA if you want to go the pEp way or not. It makes no sense to see pEp as a pure backend solution.

Sequoia PGP on the other hand is a nice, fast and handy OpenPGP library. Again, if it is about sticking with PGP then it's first choice I'd say. We at pEp are moving completely away from GnuPG now (with the exception of Enigmail, which is bound to it) and using Sequoia PGP everywhere we can.

events.target_title: Tracking: Transparent encryption and signing with GPG

note.body: When an MUA is wanting to go this way we're helping with all what we can, financing, resources, input, experience. We'll put an internal resource, too, to support. I'm fully understanding this is a big step, less in implementation and more in design. So it will be our job to support. For GNOME applications we're willing to do this.

events.target_title: Tracking: Transparent encryption and signing with GPG

note.body: pEp is secure against MITM attacks. It is delivering an appropriate trust management.

events.target_title: Implement "Jump to file" feature (type ahead)

note.body:
I'd really love to have this feature back. A better way to do a search will be to assign that feature to "Ctrl+F" and/or "/" keys.

Normal behaviour should be that the file name that I type should just get highlighted. That's a quicker and better way to navigate through a directory with many files.

events.target_title: Implement "Jump to file" feature (type ahead)

note.body:
@JoeKays I'm not really sure. It all sounds very cumbersome on the user end. If this can be considered in a positive way, I appreciate the implementation done by KDE team for Dolphin. Ctrl+L is there for editing path bar, but then there are 3 different features for the search method:
1.  A normal Search ran in current directory (which is similar to how Nautilus does things). This can be invoked using Ctrl+F.
2.  A type-ahead search (which isn't in a way it has been traditionally in other Linux file browsers). This one mimics the behaviour of how Windows' File Explorer does things. You start typing, no input box shows up for the keystrokes, and it just highlights the directory/file that matches the string entered.
3.  A filter option, that just presents file that match the input. Say, I search for "foo" in the directory (this filter bar is started by pressing the '/' key), then all the directories and files that have "foo" in their name will be listed, and other files/directories will be hidden away.

Quite honestly, number 3 is my favourite and most used feature in Dolphin. Also, I've been conditioned in a way that I expect type-ahead to work in the same way it used to work in earlier versions of Nautilus, and when it starts a directory wide search on Nautilus, it disorients me and throws me in a panic mode (of sorts), because even after all this time, this is something I don't expect my file browser to do. :frowning2:

events.target_title: GVfsd mountpoint names contain special characters (smb-share:server=svrsvrsvr.local,share=name) which breaks usability with many software titles including Wine software
GVfsd mountpoint names contain special characters (smb-share:server=svrsvrsvr.local,share=name) which breaks usability with many software titles including Wine software

note.body:
Hello. Thanks for your response.

If we were living in a purely POSIX world, I would agree, but we're dealing with known eccentricities of multiple platforms and I would assume that interoperability would have been a key decision (ie, I managed to save a file called '*.*.ods' whilst trying to display all files of all types in a save dialogue, as I wanted to match a pdf filename, but when I hit return it actually saved the file with the wildcard name, which you can imagine would cause all sorts of issues in other universes. Would this name be POSIX compliant also?)

I remember RISC OS would abstract the '.' (as used in folder name delimiters under RISC OS - SCSIFS::SCSIDisk4.$.Folder.Folder.File) from DOS filenames into '/' and back 'under the hood' when it needed to, so i.e. AUTOEXEC.BAT would be shown as AUTOEXEC/BAT.

On many platforms, the hyphen and underscore are standard placeholders, but % * . and : have certain meanings (regex, wildcards, etc).

I don't think it would be beneficial to keep these special case characters where WINE is used.

I have used soft links (I created a .gvfs folder in my home folder for ease of access) to some effect, but Libre Office (for example) is still complaining about opening files over GVfsd, which at this point, I am guessing is Libre Office's traversing of softlinks, maybe?  I honestly don't know how GVfsd presents itself to the kernel and what the 'missing parts' are compared to a local, real FS and why a piece of software would be able to notice any difference.

I would've guessed that the operation of GVfsd would be as transparent as possible, or indeed agnostic, to client applications.

Again, not wanting to be needlessly contentious, but we're living in a multi-environment world where a common denominator would ease this storm of incompatible standards.

I guess then that the GVfsd mount point names are formatted thusly for a specific reason? If not, it doesn't matter about ambiguity from the OS side, just a human seeing multiple hyphens/underscores? Although, it also depends if the mount point names are used for future reference, or even parsed for some evaluation, by GVfsd, which I would say is a house of cards waiting for a breeze :)

Is it possible to build a hierarchical structure of '<uid>/gvfs/smb/server/share' to maintain separation of mount points?

I probably just piqued a few radars with my ignorant suggestions lol :)

I hope there's no competition between the Wine team and the GVfsd team - I use both :/

Again, thanks for your quick response and apologies for my complete ignorance of the back-end.

PS: I'm off to leave my views on Libre Office's handling of remote files, now :)

events.target_title: Modernize Tracker documentation for users

note.body:
I see you're trying to centralize the documentation. I don't know if this is the best place to post, but on the Tracker wiki page I found this sentence very confusing, so maybe you can resolve along with this...

"You can configure the locations to be indexed from the GNOME Control Centre, by going to the "Search" panel and clicking the gear wheel icon"

The problem is a relatively new GNOME user is not going to know what "GNOME Control Centre", as it's now just called "Settings" from their perspective. When the sentence says 'Search' they may think it is talking about searching for applications, rather than choosing 'Search' within the Setup application.

events.target_title: Consider using Foliate's widget for ePubs/MOBI

note.body:
Hello, I'm the author of Foliate.

Foliate's "widget" is just [epub.js](https://github.com/futurepress/epub.js/). If I understand correctly, didn't Gnome Books use epub.js originally before libgepub was created?

Also Mobipocket support in Foliate (as well as Bookworm and Lector) is simply using [KindleUnpack](https://github.com/kevinhendricks/KindleUnpack) to convert Mobipocket files to EPUB files. There's also [libmobi](https://github.com/bfabiszewski/libmobi) if a C library is preferred. That should be the easiest way to provide Mobipocket support regardless of which EPUB backend Gnome Book uses.

Support application-wide dark mode preference
Support application-wide dark mode preference

note.body:
It's not a the same as #627, which is essentially asking `gtk_application_prefer_dark_theme` to be set to `true` when the view is inverted. Nor is this related to #1092, which is about the specific colors used.

This issue is about having an option to turn on/off invert/dark-theme for all documents:

Currently, night mode, like a number of other settings, is set on a per document basis. That is, each file has its own setting on whether it should be inverted. Which means that currently, if I want to enable night mode, I have to click on "Night Mode" for every document that I open. (I can use "Save Current Settings as Default", but that will only affect newly opened files.)

It would be useful if there's a way to enable/disable night mode globally--for all files.
